title: What are some of the greatest buildings that were never built? - Quora

response.answer_text: Hotel Attraction (New York City): Planned in 1908 as to be the tallest building constructed in New York City. It was designed by the architect, Antoni Gaudi. The project was considered unrealistic and hence, shelved. The Illinois (Chicago, Illinois): The mile-high skyscraper was designed by Frank Lloyd Wright in 1956. It was rejected due to several problems found in the design. Fourth Grace (Liverpool, England): Fourth Grace was considered unappealing in its design. It was conceptualized by architect Will Alsop in 2002. This project was cancelled due to ever-increasing costs in 2004. Beacon of Progress (Chicago, Illinois): The French-born architect Desire Despradelle designed this 457m stone tower in 1891. It never saw the light of day due to lack of funding. Ville Contemporaine (Paris, France): The French-Swiss architect, Le Corbusier designed it in 1922 to house about 3 million people. It was to be 60-storey skyscrapers in a steel-framed structure encompassed in glass curtain walls. It never became a reality. Tatlin’s Tower (St. Petersburg, Russia): Tatlin’s Tower was to be built from iron, steel, and glass in 1917. It was planned to surpass Eiffel Tower. Shimizu Mega-City Pyramid (Tokyo, Japan): A 2004 proposal of building a gargantuan pyramid as the largest man-made structure on the planet was planned to house 750,000 people. The project, however, never took off even from its designing phase due to lack of suitable building materials as they have not been formulated yet. Ultima Tower (San Francisco, California): The architect Eugene Tsui took inspiration from the tallest structure not made by a human while conceiving the project of Ultima Tower in 1991. Palace of Soviets (Moscow, Soviet Union): The Palace of Soviets designed by Boris Iofan was based on his winning design. It was partially constructed in 1933 and terminated later due to the German invasion. Volkshalle or The Great Dome (Berlin, Germany): Adolf Hitler and his architect, Albert Speer was planning to build it as the most important and impressive building of Berlin in 1930. However, it was stooped by the war.
My vote goes to Boulée's proposal for the Cenotaph to Isaac Newton, a solid state planetarium. Behold…
